story: Tower block residents endure bitter conditions after cladding removed and not replacedAfter living in fear for years following the Grenfell Tower fire, the type of flammable cladding which caused the lethal inferno in London was finally removed from the apartment blocksEithne and Martin Crowson of Holm Court and Plane Court in Pendleton, Salford Image: MEN MediaByJosie Le VayGraeme Murray:,  Jan | commentsHundreds of people claim they are living in bitter conditions in freezing high rise flats. Residents say the nine blocks look half-built and the windows protrude with numbers which are written in paint outside fats.And after more than four years on from the Grenfell fire in London, occupants have yet to see any replacement cladding.The blocks are can be seen from all over Salford, Manchester, but residents say the real nightmare lies inside their walls.. Lynne Broughton has lived in Thorn Court for  years. and only in the last few years she has wanted to leave.Itaposs cold, no matter how much you put the heating on itaposs freezing. I have to put blankets around my legs. I was dreading this Christmas. We have get through another winter, she told Manchester Evening News. After living in fear for years following Grenfell, the type of flammable cladding which caused the lethal inferno was finally removed from the apartment blocks in Salford in September .  The residents may no longer be living in fear of fire - but now theyaposre living in fear of the cold and the meter. This is because the buildingaposs heating system depends on the cladding to retain heat. Without it, draughts whip through the flats, which have around  residents, at a time when the cost of energy is rocketing. Before, when Iaposd switch the heating on, in half-an-hour it would be as warm as toast, Lynne said. Now, she says as soon as she walks into her flat apositaposs like being outsideapos, even though she always puts the heating on. Lynneaposs bought thick curtains, keeps her blinds down, and has put bubble wrap below her windows to try and stop the draught. But the cold isnapost the only issue caused by the cladding being removed. Many of the residents have water coming in through their exposed windows too. Ours is p***ing with rain and itaposs freezing, Lynne said of her flat. Iaposd say the majority of the block, Iaposd say itaposs the cold and the draughts and the water, she said.  If there was plenty of houses I think I would have moved out. Itaposs two years down now. Weaposre still in the cold. Whoaposs to say weaposll get the cladding later this year  They should have never have done what they did. If you donapost live in these blocks you donapost know what itaposs like. They donapost give a s**t, weaposre the poor people. Residents had previously been told that the cladding would be replaced by . Pendleton Together has now said that works are set to be complete by  - a whole two years behind schedule. Not everyone can afford the extra money thataposs needed to heat their homes. The Manchester Evening News spoke to one single mum-of-three, who doesnapost want to be named, who says she hasnapost turned her heating on for aposwell over a yearapos. She said: I donapost put the heating on at all. I sit in blankets and make the kids wrap up. I canapost afford it.  She has a newborn baby, a three-year-old and a five-year-old and wants to get out - to a flat with more than two bedrooms - and to somewhere she can afford to heat. Iaposm a single parent, where am I going to get the money to go private  she said. Instead, she survives day-by-day by spending as little time in her flat as possible. She leaves the house at am in the morning and makes her way to the warmth of her mumaposs house and doesnapostuntil itaposs time to take her children to bed. Rachel, who lives at the top of Thorn Court, says she doesnapost use her living room anymore, and has to watch TV in bed. Itaposs cold like outside. You spend most of your time in your bedroom because itaposs the warmest place, but Iaposd like to sit in the living room and chill out. It used to be dead warm but now itaposs freezing cold. You just have to put blankets on and keep the curtains shut and stuff like that, she said. Hundreds of residents across the nine blocks of flats are taking legal action against Pendleton Together, the Private Finance Initiative contractor which manages the council properties. They are claiming the properties are aposunfit for human habitationapos - mostly down to the cold. Martin Eithne and Martin Crowson are two of them. The retired couple live in Holm Court and chair the blockaposs residents association. They say that they were paying £ a week in electricity bills when the cladding was on. Now, they say theyaposre paying £.  Itaposs down to them to pay us back, Eithne said. Martin says that the biggest issue people are facing in his block is that the electric is aposcosting a fortuneapos. If you put your heating on it costs a fortune, around £ a day extra, he said. Thereaposs people that stay in bed earlier and get out of bed later because of the cladding. They canapost put the heat on because they canapost afford they canapost afford to put the heating on. Pendleton Together is giving the residents £ every two months during the winter. But everyone the M.E.N. spoke to said it was not enough. Robert Vaudrey lives in Holm Court with his we Pamela and their four-year-old daughter April. We moved in with the baby, it was our first home together, he said. The biggest problem is the heating. Since the cladding got removed, weaposre putting in £ a week.  He says the aposgesture amountsapos of money heaposs been given arenapost enough - and aposdonapost even cover a monthaposs worthapos. The payments arenapost even touching the sides, he said. Weaposve got a littlaposun. Keeping a four-year-old dressed, trying to explain that itaposs cold, itaposs just ridiculous. The heating costs so much that Pamela had the idea of covering the thermostat up with a flannel. Itaposs so the computer thinks itaposs warmer than it is. Weaposve set it to  degrees, once it goes below it takes a daft amount of money from us, Robert said. The heating may be a winter issue - but it affects the family during the summer months as well. It costs an awful lots of money, money we save up for during the summer. We have to save up. During the summer weaposve got no money to spend, Robert said. Matthew Condrad, the director of Tenant Claim, says that aposall nine of the flats have got the same issuesapos. He claims there are around  people living in the Pendleton flats - and  of them have gone to him for legal help. He said: The buildings are fitted with NIBE heating system which operates at a low temperature and relies upon the cladding to retain heat. Removal of the cladding has therefore caused excess cold which has been exacerbated by draughts around windows and ventilation ducts. The windows do not open properly and constitute a hazard. Some have also fallen out. Matthew has put forward some test cases from the Pendleton flats - andsuccessful - others will follow. But he admits that itaposs a process that could take years. And he believes that evenhe wins the case, Pendleton Together will appeal, as aposthereaposs a lot of money at stakeapos. The cladding may even be replaced by the time the cases enter the courtroom. Lynne from Thorn Court is certainly sceptical. She fears that as she accepted the apostokenapos amount of money from Pendleton Together her case would fail. She also points out, thatthe case ends up taking five years to settle, lots of the elderly claimants aposwill have carked it by A spokesperson from Pendleton Together said: Pendleton Together understands that our residents have concerns during the programme of fire safety works and we are working with them to offer support or to direct them towards services that can offer further help. As part of this support Pendleton Together Operating Limitedis providing fairly calculated winter energy payments that mitigate the dference in electricity consumption. This will mean that no resident is left out of pocket due to this dference. that timeapos. We have received reports of water ingress in some of our properties and we have responded to these. All known issues have been or are being addressed, however residents with any new concerns should contact us immediately or book a repair via our website. In relation to the timeframe for replacement of cladding, within days of the tragedy at Grenfell, Pendleton Together and Salford City Council committed to removing all cladding and insulation on our nine blocks and replacing them with safe alternatives. Unfortunately, due to well documented issues around clarity of regulation and ability to secure funding, that affects landlords nationwide, the work has taken longer than anticipated. All of the cladding has now been removed and necessary preparatory works are taking place prior to the reinstatement of cladding which is expected to start on some of our blocks in the next few months. The programme of fire safety works, which includes the replacement of cladding, the installation of sprinklers and heat detectors and other internal mitigation works is set to complete in . We are very sorry for the inconvenience and disruption that our residents are feeling. We have a dedicated team supporting our residents and keeping them informed and are doing our very best to put things in place to mitigate any disturbance. If any resident has any concerns they should contact their Resident Liaison Officer as soon as possible. Temperatures will plunge below zero before Brits see any of the white stuff - which forecasters say will last some regions of the isles on Friday, January .Forecasters see the mercury plunging to lows of -C over the next seven days with the chill remaining in the low single-digits every night and reaching just over the C mark in daylight hours. title: what bbcs tv licence how
story: What is BBCs TV licence, how much does it cost and will it be scrapped Funding for the BBC TV licence is set to be frozen for the next two years, following which it could be scrapped altogether. Heres what you need to know about paying for your TV licenceTV licence fees will be frozen at current rates for the next two years Image: Getty ImagesByMalvika Padin:,  Jan | comments The government has announced some major changes to the BBC TV licenceaposs funding model, with funds to be frozen at current rates until . There have been a series of discussions between culture secretary Nadine Dorries and BBC chiefs about how the broadcaster will be funded going forward.The culture secretary said the next announcement concerning the BBC’s licence fee “will be the last” as a new funding model is being considered for when the latest deal expires in .Here’s everything you need to know about the TV licence including why you need to pay it and what happensthe BBC gets rid of it.What is the BBCaposs TV licence fee and why do we have to pay it  TV licensing is a form of taxation which is used to raise revenue that funds the BBC. The money raised from the licence fee pays for BBC shows and services - including TV, radio, the BBC website, podcasts, iPlayer, local journalism and apps.Watching live TV without a licence is against the law and is punishable by a fine of up to £, as well as prosecution. The TV licence fee was set by the government in  and changes every year on April . Currently the rates are £ a year, and £. for black and white televisions. With Nadine Dorries considering new ways to fund the BBC, the fee is set to be frozen at the current rates until April .She wrote on Twitter : This licence fee announcement will be the last.The days of the elderly being threatened with prison sentences and bailfs knocking on doors are over. Time now to discuss and debate new ways of funding, supporting and selling great British content.Is the TV licence fee being scrapped and what will happenthe BBC gets rid of it  The BBC was expecting a rise to its licence fee to help pay for its expenses and programming during the current period of inflation. And had it taken place, the licence fee would have risen to £ a year.But the freeze at current rates of £ is set to last for two years, after which new ways to pay for the public broadcaster will be discussed again. The licence fee is expected to exist until  December , after which the government is considering introducing a subscription model to the television fee. This has been made to appeal to Conservative backbench MPs over ways to mitigate the rising cost of living, according to the Sunday Times. title: what prince harry said paying
story: What has Prince Harry said about paying for his familys security in the UK Prince Harry, the Duke of Sussex, feels he does not have sufficient security to visit the UK and has applied for a judicial review in an attempt to overturn the decision barring him from buying police protection for himself, Meghan Markle and their two childrenPrince Harry has offered to pay for his own security while in the UK, according to his lawyersByHarry Thompson:,  Jan | comments The Duke of Sussex has filed for a judicial review following the decision from the Home Office not to allow him to personally pay for police protection for himself and his family. Prince Harry and Meghan Markle have been living in the USA since  after formally stepping away from active Royal duties, sacricing the benefit of security provided by the British state.But now the prince has said he doesnapost feel the UK is a safe place for him and his family toto without the protection supplied and paid for by the government. At the time of writing, the couple pays for their own private security in the USA, where they live in Calornia.However, now he says that toto the UK without police protection would carry too great a personal risk. Harryaposs grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II, has also reportedly refused to pay for his security.Harry has argued that his US-based security team doesnapost have access to UK intelligence that would enable them to offer the best protection, and instead feels they have insufficient jurisdiction in the UK. Why does Prince Harry no longer get security for his family in the UK   The Prince and his we lost their protection, which was funded by the taxpayer, when they stepped away from senior royal duties in . Speaking to the Mail on Sunday a source said: Harryaposs argument in a nutshell is: aposYou got the law wrong.apos He feels the decision to remove his security was wrong. Pre-action protocol was sent by Harryaposs lawyers to the Home Office a couple of months ago. This is essentially a precursor to a judicial review. What has Prince Harry requested regarding security for his family in the UK   Harry wants to be able to pay for security provided by the British state. On the princeaposs behalf, a statement said: “The UK will always be Prince Harry’s home and a country he wants his we and children to be safe in, adding, Prince Harry hopes that his petition - after close to two years of pleas for security in the UK - will resolve this situation. As part of an official statement, the princeaposs legal spokesperson said: Prince Harry inherited a security risk at birth, for le. He remains sixth in line to the throne, served two tours of combat duty in Afghanistan, and in recent years his family has been subjected to well-documented neo-Nazi and extremist threats. While his role within the institution has changed, his profile as a member of the royal family has not. Nor has the threat to him and his family.  “The Duke and Duchess of Sussex personally fund a private security team for their family, yet that security cannot replicate the necessary police protection needed whilst in the UK. In the absence of such protection, Prince Harry and his family are unable toto his home. “The duke first offered to pay personally for UK police protection for himself and his family in January of  at Sandringham. That offer was dismissed. He remains willing to cover the cost of security, so as not to impose on the British taxpayer. As is widely known, others who have left public office and have an inherent threat risk receive police protection at no cost to them. “The goal for Prince Harry has been simple – to ensure the safety of himself and his family while in the UK so his children can know his home country.” Following a visit to the UK for the unveiling of a statue of his late mum, Princess Diana, his car was chased by photographers leaving him feeling anxious about the state of his security in the UK. story: WhatsApp announces major update to service - heres how to try it out firstUsers of the app will be able to see what friends and family really think of their messages when it brings in a major change to show reactions in a similar way to FacebookWhatsApp users will soon be able to react to messages in a similar way to Facebook Image: Getty ImagesByCiaran DalyRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsWhatsApp has announced a major change to the service which will give friends and family the chance to react to what you say. In plans being rolled out to some users already, the reactwill give users the opportunity to show their feelings in the same way as on Facebook. And phone users will even be able to manage message-reaction notications without unlocking.Though the update is yet to be installed en masse, some users will be able to use the technology, the Daily Star reports.IPhone users will get first dibs on the update - with changes expected to allow the management of group and inidual chat notications. Itaposs currently unknown when Android users will have the opportunity to use the neat feature. Anyone can download an update now through the appaposs Beta program. By signing up, users can test the latest experimental features for the app, some of which will never be seen by the general public.  While the update gives you the ability to manage message reactions, it doesnapost actually let you react to messages just yet. WhatsApp insiders WABetaInfo said: You are now able to manage when you should receive notications for reactions, for inidual chats and groups, and which tone to play when you receive those notications. Unfortunately, itaposs still not possible to react to messages, but the fact itaposs possible to manage these settings suggests that message reactions will be available very soon. Hereaposs how to register for the new update and try it out before everyone Open WhatsApp and tap the three dots, then head to aposMore Optionsapos Tap Linked Devices Hit aposMulti-device betaapos Tap aposJoin betaaposOnce youaposve joined the beta programme, youaposll be able to try out every new version of WhatsApp before it is released to the general public. title: man reviews biggest tea brands
story: Man reviews biggest tea brands in UK - and announces an unlikely winnerLewis Smith, journalist for Wales Online, decided to settle one of the nations great debates and find out which brand of tea is the best of them all - and his verdict might upset one or two peopleLewis reviewed each of the most popular tea brands in the UK Image: Lewis SmithByLewis SmithJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsItaposs the nationaposs favourite drink by a long way, with nothing quite so British as waking up to a nice cuppa to start the day off right.We Brits love our tea, with a good old mug of English breakfast being our favourite type as boxes of the stuff sit in kitchens up and down the UK. But with so many dferent brands to choose from, sometimes itaposs impossible to know which type to go for in the supermarket. Luckily, a reporter for Wales Online has done the heavy lting for the rest of us, sitting down to a proper tea tasting test to determine the best brand. Reporter Lewis Smith sat down with six brands: Tetley, Twinings, Yorkshire Tea, PG Tips, Tesco Original and a special Welsh blend, Paned Gymreig.  For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Using ml of water and a splash of milk in each cup, Lewis judged the taste of each brew to figure out which was best. First sitting down with a mug of Paned Gymreig, Lewis noted its rich taste and golden brown flavour. Despite a fairly satisfying taste test, he admitted it didnapost blow me away, and gave it a respectable .  rating. Next Lewis sat down with a slightly more expensive brand, Twinings Everyday. But, despite the fact it could be described as premium, Lewis was underwhelmed by the taste of the cuppa and decided some of the cheaper brands were much tastier. Bearing in mind price versus taste, Lewis gave it an unimpressive rating of  . Next up was PG Tips, a well known and moderately priced teabag that is a firm favourite in many households. He noted the lovely smell that greeted him as he opened the box of teabags, and said the taste lived up to the aroma. After admitting he could sit around and drink PG Tips all day, he gave the brand  . His fourth cuppa was a mugful of Yorkshire Tea - which could be argued to be the most popular brand of tea in the UK.  But Lewisaposs verdict will leave many fans of the northern brew upset, as he gave it a measly rating of . . Explaining his reasoning, Lewis said: It was one of my least favourite drinks due to the uniquely robust flavour that was not to my preference. He did admit, however, that the cup of Yorkshire Tea looked more appealing than most others he tested. Cuppa number five was a blend of Tesco Original, which came in at a bargain price - and Lewis reckoned he got more than enough for his money. Describing the cuppa as incredibly light and rich, he said it was another brew he could sit and drink all day. In what could be a surprising verdict for many, he gave the Tesco cuppa a rating of . . Finally, Lewis poured himself a cup of Tetley tea, another firm UK favourite that has been on the shelves since . Describing Tetley as his previous go-to choice for a brew, he realised on this taste test that it didnapost offer the same quality of flavour heaposd had from the PG Tips and Tesco options. Still, he offered it a respectable . . After sitting down with each cuppa, Lewis was adamant that Tesco Original was his favourite cuppa - closely followed by PG Tips. As for family favourites like Yorkshire Tea and Twinings, he could take or leave them - which is likely to ide Brits around the country. story: Mum left mortied after accidentally sending son to school with worst lunch everA mum was left in hysterics when she realised shed given her son the wrong packed lunch. She shared the blunder on Mumsnet where users shared stories of their own Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsThereaposs no such thing as a perfect parent. With one hundred and one tasks to tackle, itaposs inevitable that there are slip-ups along the way - as one mum found out. A woman was left in hysterics after she made the honest mistake of giving her son the wrong packed lunch.The woman took to Mumsnet to share the hilarious blunder, where she explained she was supposed to give her son pasta salad for his packed lunch.But it was when he asked why sheaposd given him funny mashed potato instead, she realised her mistake. Taking to the parenting site, she wrote: I told DS [darling son] he had pasta salad for lunch, she said. This evening he asked why we’d given him aposfunny mashed potatoapos instead. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Turns out the pasta salad was still in the fridge and he’d been eating a tub full of fat I’d saved for the birds. Has anyone sent their child to school with anything worse or are we officially the worst parents on Mumsnet  she concluded her post. One person said: No, but this made me laugh out loud after a busy day! How much of it did he eat ! Ahahahahahaha!!!! Oh dear, said another. A third laughed: Iaposm surprised you didnapost get a confused call from the school receptionist!! Someone  said: Crying with laughter here - you definitely win the award for the worst packed lunch ever. Others shared funny stories of their own. We sent our son to school with a tub of margarine once, said one woman. Another added: My brother once opened his lunchbox at school to find therein a banana that was past its best covered in biscuit crumbs. Brother was only very little at the time so a banana and a few biscuits might havebeen an adequate lunch as a one-off. But the biscuits didn’t survive the journey being swung about by a -year-old, so a crumb-coated banana was lunch that day. A third then said: I had a bit of a rep for sending my kids to school with sandwiches made from mouldy bread.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: mum 24 sheds 6st military
story: Mum, , sheds st with military workout regime after eating McDonalds every dayMum-of-one Alex Moore, , from Adelaide in Australia, gained five-and-a-half stone while pregnant with daughter Alora and found herself eating from fast food joint McDonalds "at least" once a day for four monthsAlex Moore, , stacked on the weight during her pregnancy and would eat McDonalds at least once a day Image: Jam Press @alexpaigemooreByOlivia Loveridge-GreenRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A mum who ate McDonaldaposs at least once a day during her pregnancy has lost an incredible six stone – thanks to a gruelling military-style workout regime.Alex Moore, , from Adelaide, Australia, gained five-and-a-half stone while pregnant with her daughter Alora, now -months-old.Fed up with her “mum tum” and weighing st lbs, she decided to get in shape, swapping burgers for protein-rich meals. Following what she calls a strict military regime – which saw her take daily am visits to the gym and embark on km walks, working out for two-and-a-half hours a day – the mum-of-one managed to shed six stone in nine months.Despite being in better physical shape than before she had children, Alex says her meals are now bigger than what they were before – but packed with nutritious ingredients. She found out she was pregnant at the end of  and says midway through her pregnancy she began to eat unhealthily, causing her to pile on the pounds. “I really stacked on the weight – I was working long hours as a dental nurse and would eat McDonaldaposs at least once a day,” Alex, a former dental nurse, said.  I was starting early I’d usually get hash brown, egg and bacon muffin and hot chocolate for breakfast. And then for lunch I’d order a Quarter Pounder or Big Mac meal, a chocolate sundae and extra chicken nuggets with mayo. My mental health throughout most of my pregnancy was fine, however I did struggle towards the end realising how much weight I had gained and not recognising myself.” Alex welcomed her daughter in May  – but found herself feeling uncomfortable with her body. She said: I didnapost want to go out anywhere to show her off, I just wanted to hide away. I felt guilty Iaposd given birth to a beautul baby girl but I was so embarrassed about how I looked so never wanted my picture taken with her. I constantly heard was aposyour body will never be the sameapos and aposyou will always have a mum tum, learn to love itapos.  I didnapost want to be like that, so I used it as motivation. Alex decided that enough was enough and began to get in shape by hitting the gym and overhauling her diet. She said: I worked my a** off at the gym going at am every morning and going for km walks every day. At first I was really strict on my diet. I probably went too hard and developed somewhat of an eating disorder.  Iaposve now worked out a healthy relationship with food and exercise. Before I was only eating three small meals a day. Now I have larger meals and snacks. I donapost really count macros, or calories. I just try to eat mainly whole foods, regularly. I eat three main meals a day and have a snack in the morning which may be a protein bar, protein shake or a bit of fruit. In the afternoon I snack on a yoghurt but I try to listen to my body. I no longer turn down opportunities to eat out, and enjoy treats without guilt.  Alongside her healthy diet, Alex decided to ditch cardio and HIIT workouts in favour of weight training in a bid to gain lean muscle. She has currently shed six stone – and is healthier than ever. Her impressive weight loss has even let Alex change careers, swapping dental nursing for the glamourous le of an OnlyFans model.  She said: I saw it as a good source of income being a single mum having my daughter majority of the time. Now I can spend my days with Alora, and still make a good income. Alex shared a video documenting her weight loss to her , TikTok followers, who showered the mum-of-one with praise. One TikTok user said: This is what hard work and discipline looks like queens! Good job mumma. A second follower added: I literally gasped, this is amazing. Such an amazing transformation. Well done,” said another fan. One inspired viewer commented: Youaposre doing amazing Alex, itaposs empowering watching you.” While someone  said: Yes mama. You look awesome. Speaking about how her journey may inspire others, Alex added: I really want to show other mums what you can achieve when you set goals and are determined enough to achieve them. I also want people to know that itaposs important not to neglect self-care just because youaposre a mother – youaposre allowed to treat yourself and do things just for yourself. title: nurse caught injecting vaccine tissue
story: Nurse caught injecting vaccine into a tissue before issuing Covid pass in scamAccording to investigators in Italy there was a network of dozens of scammers who brought people from across Italy to a vaccination centre in AnconaThe nurse was caught at a vaccine centre in Italy Image: Polizia Di StatoByWilliam Walker:,  Jan  A nurse was caught aposinjectingapos doses of a Covid vaccine into a tissue before giving patients a faked vaccination pass in a huge scam.The racket which helped people to get a vaccine passport without ever having to take a dose of the jab was caught by Italian police. According to investigators there was a network of dozens of scammers who brought people from across Italy to a vaccination centre in Ancona. There people would pay about £ for the fake jab before being handed a aposgreen passapos which shows proof that a person has been vaccinated. One nurse at the Paolinelli sports centre vaccine centre was caught squirting a dose of the vaccine into a rubbish bin before sticking a plaster on to the patient so it looked authentic.  The police unit in Ancona, which is in north east Italy, uncovered people who wanted to avoid having the vaccine before bribing a -year-old nurse who ran a vaccination centre. A video of the fraud shows the nurse and the patient pretending to get the injection when she in fact reaches over and injects the contents of the syringe into a bin. The nurse was later arrested and put into preventive custody, while four people including a -old-lawyer from Ancona who acted as intermediaries for the scam were placed under house arrest. Police are investigating about  people as part of their operation, which was launched in December last year, and they have been ordered not to leave the region and to present themselves on a daily basis to the local force. The gang were charged with wasting public resources as well as undermining the effectiveness of the public health work of the Italian national health system in order to tackle the spread of Covid. Police also seized £,that had been gained from people who had fraudulently paid for the fake vaccine. The consultant paediatrician at what was then the Royal Hospital for Sick Children at Yorkhill was a leading light in neo-natal medicine. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: long covid recovery diary
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowOur hearts go out to everyone involved with the Nancy Glen tragedy.For the grieving families, the many people who valiantly tried to save the boat, everyone involved in the search for and recovery of the trawler and many more besides the ordeal of re-living the events of four years ago cannot have been easy.The ultimate outcome of the Fatal Accident Inquiry must be to help avoid such tragedies from happening again.The evidence given was technical, traumatic and deeply sad. There were many contributing factors according to the sherf, some of which would have been avoided with the crystal clear benefit of hindsight.As the sherf noted, the owners took pride in their vessel, kept it well maintained and considered it to be a safe boat. They were managing it little dferently to many others up and down the Scottish coast.But, crucially, no stability rules applied to boats like the Nancy Glen at the time of the accident.Duncan MacDougall was an experienced fisherman who knew these waters well and,it could happen to his boat, there is an obvious need to raise awareness to prevent such devastating accidents in future.

title: neil-hastings-leaves-gala-new-full-time-role-football
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers have announced the appointment of Martin ‘Jimmy’ Scott and Stevie Craig as their new management team until the end of the season following the departure of Neil Hastings to an undisclosed full-time role in football.Scott has been with the club for six months as first team coach and then Assistant Manager and is relishing the opportunity to take charge of the Lowland League outfit.He has appointed former Aberdeen player, Steven Craig, as his Assistant Manager and he will join the club this week.Club Chairman, Ryan Cass, added: “Three seasons ago we lost our way a little and lost our identity, it was so important we got that back. When Neil was appointed, he knew how important it was for Gala to play a certain way. His philosophy matched the club’s which was really exciting.“When the club decided to appoint Neil there were a few people outside the club that were very surprised as we finished in th place the season before but we knew that we got the right man for the job to bring back that identity and produce a team that the town could be proud of.“Since then we have gone from strength to strength and it has been the most successful period of the club’s history with a th place league finish and progressing to the third round of the Scottish Cup this year narrowly being defeated by League  contenders Annan Athletic.“I can’t thank Neil, the coaching staff and the players enough over the last few seasons and wish him all the best for the future. It didn’t surprise me when a club from the top-flight came calling as his coaching skills are second to none but most importantly as a person he is a great guy that wants to constantly learn and develop as a coach.“He has built a tremendous team spirit here at Gala which hasn’t gone unseen as the season tickets sales have been on the rise for the last two seasons.“The club wishes him good luck to not only our now ex-manager but to our friend and no doubt he’ll progress even further in the game..remove“We also want to wish Martin Scott and Steven Craig along with coach Colin McCall all the very best for the rest of the season.”

title: hastings-thanks-board-players-volunteers-support
story: Neil Hastings has left Gala Fairydean Rovers with ‘fond memories’ and has thanked the board, players and volunteers for their support during his time at the club.Hastings took over at Netherdale in the summer of  and made an immediate on the club with his professionalism, ambition and passion.He led Rovers to their highest league finish last season and everyone at the club wish him well in his new full-time post in the game.Hastings said: “Firstly, I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Chairman and the Board for their belief and trust in giving me my first managerial post back in May . They have continued to support and help me during my time at the club and for that I will be forever grateful.“Secondly, I would like to thank everyone behind the scenes at the club. At Gala this group is not a huge number and all of them are volunteers and at any level there is a lot of time  work that must be put in to get games on.“Washing strips, setting up goals, running turnstiles and hospitality, are all jobs that need to be done and both the players and I appreciate it.“Finally, I need to thank all of the players and every member of staff who have been at the club during my time. Please believe me none of them pay their mortgage from being at the club but their commitment  the sacrices they have made have been second to none.“I believe we currently have a fantastic group of players and staff who I have enjoyed working and spending time with!“In football there are many ups and downs and during my time at the club this has been no dferent. We have had positive results and disappointing results and performances, but the most frustrating thing is we haven’t been able to complete a full season during my time due to each season being prematurely finished due to covid.“I leave a fantastic club with good people who have good morals  beliefs. I leave with fond memories and friends for le. Thanks, and take care.”.removeClub Chairman, Ryan Cass, added: “I can’t thank Neil, the coaching staff and the players enough over the last few seasons and wish him all the best for the future. It didn’t surprise me when a club from the top-flight came calling as his coaching skills are second to none but most importantly as a person he is a great guy that wants to constantly learn and develop as a coach.“He has built a tremendous team spirit here at Gala which hasn’t gone unseen as the season tickets sales have been on the rise for the last two seasons.“The club wishes him good luck to not only our now ex-manager but to our friend and no doubt he’ll progress even further in the game.”Hastings will be replaced by his assistant Martin Scott.

title: sbc-lose-power-stop-removal-phone-boxes
story: BORDERS MP, John Lamont, has criticised plans that would lead to the removal of most of the remaining phone boxes in the Borders.Proposed plans by Ofcom, the telecommunications regulator, would see local authorities like Scottish Borders Council lose a veto over the removal of phone boxes.The proposed criteria to protect public call boxes would be where they do not have coverage from all four mobile network providers, they are located in an accident or suicide hotspot, they have made more than  calls over the past  months or there is a relevant exceptional circumstance that demonstrates a need for a public call box.It is understood that most phone boxes in the Borders would not meet these criteria and be removed.Therefore, Mr Lamont has responded to the consultation asking that they adopt existing Scottish Borders Council criteria for retaining public call boxes.The Borders MP highlighted in his response the importance of public phones, especially during emergencies like Storm Arwen.He said: “Storm Arwen ripped out the ability of many Borderers to communicate, with no phone service and no electricity to charge their mobile.“Phone boxes provide a backup in these situations when people need to phone the emergency services for help.“I know that lots of people will not have used a phone box in years, and no doubt many young people have never used one. But they remain a vital part of our phone network.“If Ofcom decides to remove the veto of local authorities, then we must do all we can to strengthen their criteria for retaining the public call boxes.“Scottish Borders Council already has a very effective set of criteria that they have applied locally, and I think these should be adopted by Ofcom nationally.“I have made these points very clear in my consultation response.”Leader of Scottish Borders Council, Cllr Mark Rowley, said: "Rural phone boxes still have a role whilst some areas - like the box  yards from my home in a remote Berwickshire village remain mobile not-spots and are close to recreational routes..remove“Storm Arwen showed just how fragile our communications are. The odd analogue phone still worked when mobile masts were out of power, fibre broadband was dead and power cut all telephony.“Ofcom now has a great opportunity here to ensure that all rural communities that need it get a community connectivity hub with an updated phone box with a reserve power supply which could be a leline in remote areas and for those travelling through them.“Scottish Borders Council has always made a robust case to retain such vital infrastructure, we now ask that it be updated to be able to respond to the challenges our infrastructure clearly faces and I welcome support of our MPs to help make that case to Ofcom.”

title: 20mph-limits-borders-council-vehicle-clocked-58mph-data-suggests
story: A COUNCIL vehicle was clocked travelling at mph in a mph zone in the Borders, figures obtained via a Freedom of Informationrequest suggest.Last month, elected members backed plans to make the limits – which had been introduced as part of trial – permanent across the region.According to the data released by the local authority, between November - a total of  council vehicles fitted with trackers broke the mph speed restrictions.Responding to the figures, a Scottish Borders Councilspokesperson said that there were “some discrepancies” where vehicles were logged in mph zones when actually on mph roads.:Class A drugs seized following police operation in HawickThe spokesperson said: “The council expects everyone to abide by the speed limits in place on our local roads. Our staff are no exception to this and this will once again be reiterated to them by senior management.“In respect of this data, further interrogation has revealed some discrepancies, where the system has logged apparent speeding over mph when in fact the vehicle was in an area where a mph limit is in place.”There were  incidents of council vehicles driving between mph-mph and  incidents between mph-mph, according to the data.Figures revealed thanks to the FoI request – submitted by A Non – also show that a top speed of mph was hit during November.SBC said that senior management would speak to employees back in June when a similar FoI request revealed that there had been  ‘pinged’ incidents of vehicles breaking the mph limits between February -.:Three teenagers reported following vandal attacks in Borders town, say policeThe mph limits have proved controversial in the Borders, with SBC officers receiving death threats in a public survey on the new measures.The restrictions were rolled out across the region in October  as part of an -month trial..removeThe aim of the scheme is to make it easier for people to safely walk and cycle during everyday journeys.At a meeting in December, SBC elected officials voted in favour of making mph the ‘default’ limit in the Borders – although some mph and mph buffer zones are in place.Gordon Edgar, SBC’s executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport, said the introduction of the scheme was a “bold step”.

title: westruther-council-planning-chiefs-overruled-house-bid
story: ELECTED officials have overruled the council’s planning officers after backing a proposal near a Borders village due to “exceptional circumstances”.The applicant, Donald McLeod, sought planning permission in principle to build a house close to Westruther with “specialist facilities” to accommodate the family’s specic health and welfare needs.Scottish Borders Councilroad officials objected to the development due it being unsafe for pedestrians to walk between the village and the proposed site.But members of the local authority’s planning and building standards committee supported the applicant at a meeting on Monday , with Mid Berwickshire councillor Donald Moffat describing it as “the right thing to do”.Council leader Mark Rowley, of the Conservatives, took the “very rare” step of calling in the application.Speaking at the meeting he said: “I initiated the call in after becoming aware of the McLeod family’s very unique challenges and the equally unique opportunity to mitigate them here on this site thanks to the generous support of neighbours.”The leader, who is also a Mid Berwickshire councillor, added that the house would “keep the family at the heart of their community”.According to Barry Fotheringham, SBC principal planning officer, the community council and seven healthcare professionals gave their support to the house proposal.But SBC planning officials recommended that the application should be refused due to pedestrian safety concerns, as well as the potential for “a signicant adverse impact upon the composition and quality of the landscape character”.A report published ahead of the meeting states: “Whilst acknowledging the applicant’s personal circumstances, there are no material planning considerations that would support the erection of a dwelling in this particular location, and there are no known extenuating circumstances or other material considerations, which indicate support for this development as an exception from the Local Development Plan. Regrettably, the principle of development is not considered acceptable in this location.”.removeIt adds: “The planning authority understands the applicant’s circumstances and need to find alternative, fit for purpose family accommodation that meets their very specic needs. Unfortunately, their very specic personal circumstances are not material to the assessment of this application and cannot be taken into account when determining the acceptability, or otherwise, of the proposed development.”However, at the meeting Mr Moffat, of the SNP, moved a formal proposal to approve the plans which was seconded by Hawick representative Clair Ramage.He said: “The family want to stay in the community where they have got a support mechanism. It’s important in cementing a local community together and stopping rural depopulation.“These are definitely exceptional circumstances. In pure planning terms I’ve heard what has been said and normally you wouldn’t take certain things into consideration.“I don’t often disagree with the planning officers [but] I would quite happily approve this in principle because it’s the right thing to do.”

title: scott-praises-efforts-departing-boss-hastings
story: MARTIN ‘Jimmy’ Scott says he is "honoured and excited" to take over as manager of Gala Fairydean Rovers.The former Ross County and Hibs player joined Rovers last summer as assistant to Neil Hastings, who has left the club for a full-time position.Scott has appointed former Aberdeen player Steven Craig as his number two and he will join the club this week.Speaking following his appointment the new gaffer said: “I’m honoured and excited to be appointed manager of the club and I am really looking forward to getting started this week.“It will be a smooth transition for me, and this is credit to the players, staff and everyone who’s involved in the operation of the club.“I’ve worked very closely with Neil over the last six months and ultimately the philosophy will remain the same in how we want to approach the game although I will always keep putting the demands on the players to improve on the good work already done.“I have added Steven Craig to assist with first team operations and to attract someone of Stevie’s pedigree shows what a fantastic club we have here and he’s very excited to start working with myself, staff and the squad.“On a personal note, I’m absolutely delighted for Neil moving to a full-time position in football. He certainly deserves that opportunity and I have no doubt he will be a huge success.“Anyone associated with the club would agree this day would eventually arrive as he has a big future in coaching and management, and he certainly leaves Gala with everyone’s best wishes.”Neil Hastings took charge of the club back in  and made an immediate impact with his professionalism, ambition and passion.He led the Fairydean Rovers to their highest league finish last season.

title: borders-author-backs-plans-pardon-witches
story: WOMEN and men from across the Borders who were convicted of witchcraft and subsequently executed could finally be pardoneda private members bill becomes law this year.In  in Scotland the Witchcraft Act was enacted and remained in law until .The vast majority of those accused, some  per cent, were women.Trials began all over Scotland, with three times the number of witchcraft prosecutions than England and five times the European average.By the time the act was repealed there were an estimated , people who had been accused and tried although that number could be higher due to a lack of available records.And historians believe that more witches were accused, tried and executed in the Scottish Borders than any other area of Scotland except Edinburgh and the Lothians.Stow-based author Mary Craig who wrote the book Borders Witch Hunt supports the call for a pardon.She says around  people were trialled in the Borders.Ms Craig said: “As a country we are rightly proud of Robert the Bruce and William Wallace so we should acknowledge the bad things we have done. I’m not a lawyer so there may be some legal arguments against a pardon, but I would support this bill.“In the Scottish Borders alone there were around  women and men brought to trial resulting in around  being executed. Another  died of ill-treatment or just the poor conditions in prison so the numbers in the region were pretty high when you consider there wasn’t much of a population at that time.“And It wasn’t all that long ago, in fact there was a woman from Selkirk executed in . If it happened today there would be demonstrations outside the High Court and the Parliament but in those days the church was so powerful.“So I think there should also be an apology and in my opinion a national monument, not just for the women and men accused but also for their families.”The bill is being put forward to SNP MSP Natalie Don, who is looking for cross-party support..removeIf approved in the Scottish Parliament, a pardon would be secured for those convicted under the Witchcraft Act.Ms Don said: “I’ve already had support from my own group the SNP who are happy for me to take this forward and now I’ll be looking for cross party support.“Its essentially admitting that this wasnt a criminal act and that these people shouldnt go down in history as criminals. They should be given a posthumous pardon.”The bill has secured the support of First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and could be passed as early as this summer.

title: minister-fled-extremism-joins-peeblesshire-churches
story: A MINISTER who fled extremism in Pakistan has been inducted at Peebles Parish Church.Reverend Aftab Gohar moved to the town earlier this month after joining from Abbotsgrange in Grangemouth.Originally from Peshawar in Pakistan, the -year-old, his we Samina and their two sons came to Scotland in  to escape the threat of terrorism.But in  the Gohar family suffered a tragedy when Aftabs -year-old mother, his niece, nephew and two uncles were killed when extremists targeted his home church in Peshawar.The attack was later claimed by two militant groups linked to the Taliban.At the time, Rev Gohar told the BBC that he forgave the suicide attackers, saying: "It is wrong what these people did but I forgive them".When the incident happened, Aftab was the minister at Abbotsgrange Parish Church.But after more than a decade in the Forth Valley, he says it is time for a change.He told us: "After  years we wanted to move on and Peebles, with all its scenery and beauty, invited us to come here."We visited this town three or four times."Once on our wedding anniversary we came to Peebles and stayed here."We like the scenery and the town as a whole."Rev. Gohar held his first services in Peebles and Stobo on January  and his first in Eddleston on January .And he says parishioners have been more than welcoming."Ive really enjoyed meeting people in all three churches," he added.As part of his ministry Rev. Gohar wants to engage with the Peeblesshire community.He said: "I will try to reach out to the community and serve the community through other ministries, I served in Rotary [before] which is a non-church thing but I love to help the community in dferent ways."My style of ministry is pastoral, so I would love to reach out to people."I will not just rely on those people who come to the church on Sunday morning, I will try to reach out to members who are unable to come to church for a iety of reasons..remove"My hopes are that these three churches will flourish and work together for the kingdom of God."

title: downing-street-party-borders-mps-respond-criticism-response
story: THE two Borders MPs have responded to criticism from the opposition over their response to reports of Downing Street parties during lockdown.On Wednesday , Boris Johnson admitted he attended a ‘bring your own booze’ gathering at No  in May .Following the admission, Colin Smyth, of Scottish Labour, called on Tory representatives in the region to “have the guts to stand up for their constituents and condemn these actions without delay”.Also commenting after Prime Minister’s Questions , Borders MP John Lamont said it was "completely unacceptable that this event went ahead", adding that he did not understand how anyone attending could have thought it was compliant with the rules.Tweeddale MP David Mundell said that an opportunity for a “full, straightforward explanation” to the allegations was missed on Wednesday.:Borders MP criticises plans to remove most phone boxes in the regionSpeaking in the House of Commons, Mr Johnson offered his “heartfelt apologies” for attending the garden ‘party’ during the first lockdown. The Prime Minister told MPs that the gathering was “technically within the rules” but that he should have realised how it would look.Criticising Conservative figures in the region, Mr Smyth said: “Despite weeks of coverage of Downing Street parties during lockdown, local Tory MPs and MSPs have failed to utter one word of criticism of their leader. They are a complete disgrace.“The idea that while people were dying in hospital from this terrible virus and our amazing NHS was battling with untold horrors trying to keep them alive, the Tories were holding parties attended by the Prime Minister is completely disgusting, as is the failure of local Tory politicians to condemn these actions.”Senior civil servant Sue Gray is investigating whether coronavirus rules were broken at a number of lockdown get-togethers.At least  alleged gatherings, in Downing Street or government departments, have come to light so far..remove:Police seek help to trace good Samaritan after -year-old man assaulted in DunsOn the No  garden gathering, John Lamont, Conservative MP for Roxburgh, Berwickshire and Selkirk, said: “It is completely unacceptable that this event went ahead. I do not understand who could have organised or attended such an event and thought it was compliant with the rules.“Anyone not following the rules we have all been expected to should be held responsible. That is only fair to those of us who diligently complied with restrictions for months on end.”Responding to Mr Smyth’s comments, Mr Mundell said: “I do not believe the way events have unfolded, let alone the idea of parties during lockdown, are acceptable and, to be clear, I have myself never attended any such gathering."There have been calls, which I support, for a full explanation of the events in question to be given before the publication of the ongoing report by the independent civil servant Sue Gray.“Certainly, I cannot see that offering this information could in any way prejudice the outcome of the report, and it would provide the public with answers to which they are most definitely entitled in these circumstances.”:Council vehicle clocked at mph in mph zone in Borders, FoI data suggestsThe Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale MP added: “This week in the House of Commons was an opportunity for that full, straightforward explanation to be given, but I regret that I do not believe it was taken.“Along with everyone , I will now await the outcome of the report by Ms Gray.”Following PMQs, Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross called on Mr Johnson to resign.“I don’t want to be in this position, but I am in this position now, where I don’t think he can continue as leader of the Conservatives,” said Mr Ross.He added that there was “signicant unrest and concern” among Tories either side of the border.
